bibl.title: Plains Cree Texts
bibl.series: Publications of the American Ethnological Society, Volume XVI

encodingdesc.p: This electronic document is oriented more toward representing those features that seem most likely to be relevant for grammatical analyses, rather than toward faithfully representing all the information available in the book.

list.item: 2014 06 10; KR; UTF-8, paragraph and sentence numbering, smart-quotes in English translations

p.seg: kîtahtawê pêyak awa nâpêw , êh-nîsicik owîkimâkanah , itah êh-wîkicik . Once upon a time there was a man who lived alone somewhere with only his wife.
mâcîw awa nâpêw . The man used to hunt.

kâ-nipahât mostoswah , êh-takohtêt owîkiwâhk , êh-wîhtamawât owîkimâkanah , wawêyîw awâ iskwêw , êh-wîh-nâtahk wiyâsah . When he had killed buffalo, as he arrived at their tipi and told his wife, the woman would make ready to fetch the meat.
astis manipitam , êh-matostêhahk iskotêhk . She would pull out a dried sinew and scorch it in the fire.
papêtikôhkahtêw astisis . The sinew would shrivel up small.
ômis îsi ta-kisiwâkiwiw , kâ-wîh-nâtamân wiyâsah ! itwêw awah iskwêw . “Even thus let it be near whence I am to fetch the meats!” she would say.

êkosi êh-wayawît , ê-sipwêhtêt , êh-nâtahk wiyâsah , tâpwêw kisiwâk otihtam , êh-otinahk , êh-kîwêhtatât . Thereupon, when she left the tipi and went forth to fetch the meat, she would in fact come to it close by, and take it and bring it home.

wâh , itêyihtam awa nâpêw ,
tâpwê kâh-kiyipah pêtâw wiyâsah , itêyihtam . “Dear me,” thought the man, “truly she is always quick about bringing the meat,” thought he.
êkosi kîtahtawê kiskêyihtam wîwah êh-misikitiyit , êh-pwâwiyit . Then presently he know that his wife was big with child.
pôtih kîtahtawê âhkosiyiwa ôwîkimâkanah , ê-wîh-wâpamâcik ôh âwâsisah . Presently, there, his wife fell ill, for they were about to see their child.
tâpwê êh-tipiskâyik , pahkisiniyiwa . And indeed, when darkness came, she was forced to her couch.
wâpamêwak awâsisah . They saw their child.
mistahi miywêyihtam awa nâpêw êh-otawâsimisiyit wîwah êyôkonih . The man was very glad that his wife had given birth to a child.
êyôkoh êkwah wîsahkêcâhk . And this child was Wisahketchahk.
êkosi kanawêyimêwak , êw-ohpikihâcik . So they cared for him and brought him up.
piyis misikitiw awa wîsahkêcâhk . In time this Wisahketchahk grew big.
âsay mîna ocawâsimisiwak . Again they had a child.
mîn êwakô nihtâwikiw . This one, too, was born.
êwako mîna nâpêsis . This one, too, was a boy.
osîmisiw wîsahkêcâhk . Wisahketchahk had a little brother.
miywêyihtam êh-osîmisit . He was glad of it.
êkwah êkotah ay-ayâwak . So they lived in that place.
piyisk misikitiwak ôkih awâsisak . In time those children grew big.
êkwah pisisik mâcîw awa nâpêw . And that man did nothing but hunt.
êkwah aw îskwêw êh-nikohtêt mânah , nah-nama-mayaw takohtêw aw iskwêw . Now, when that woman gathered firewood, she had a way of not coming back on time.

namoya êkwah atoskêw êkoyikohk , itêyimêw ôwîkimâkanah awa nâpêw , osâm kâh-kinwêsk êh-nikohtêyit ; “Now, she does not work as long as this,” thought the man of his wife, when again and again she took too long about gathering wood;
tânis âwah tiyôtahk ? itêyimêw ; “What is it she does?” he thought of her;

seg.gloss: “I had better try and find out what sort of thing delays her;

p.seg: osâm kâ-kapê-kîsik nikohtêw . êh-itêyimât owîkimâkanah . she is all day gathering firewood,” thought he of his wife.

kîkisêpâ wawêyîw , ê-wîh-mâcît , ê-sipwêhtêt , êkwah itêh kâ-nikohtêyit owîkimâkanah , êkotê êh-itohtêt . The next morning he made ready to go hunting and set out and went to where his wife got firewood.
êkotah kâsôhtawêw owîkimâkanah . There he hid from his wife.
kîtahtawê kâ-pêc-âstamohtêyit , êh-pê-nikohtêyit . Presently she came walking that way, at her task of getting firewood.
êh-pê-takohtêyit êkotah sakâhk , kâ-wâpamât ê-misikitiyit mistikwah êh-kîskipayiyit . When she arrived there in the grove, he noticed a large cleft tree.
êkotah nîpawiyiwah ôwîkimâkanah , êh-kêtayôwinisêyit , ê-mosêskatêyit . By it his wife took her stand, and took off her clothes until she stood naked.
otinam mistik aw îskwêw , ôhi mistikwah kâ-misikitiyit êh-pa-pakamahwât aw îskwêw . She took up a stick and began to beat that large tree.

ômis îtwêw :
ninâpêmitik ! itwêw , kâ-wâpamât awa nâpêw mihcêt êh-wayawiyit mistikohk ohci kinêpikwah . This was what she said: “O my husbands!” she said, and then the man saw a great many serpents come forth from the tree.

êkosi nahapiw aw îskwêw , êh-pimisihk , misiwê êkotah êh-papâmâhtawêyit ôhi kinêpikwah aw îskwêw wiyawihk . At that the woman lay down flat and those serpents climbed this way and that all over her body.
piyisk namoya wâpamêw owîkimâkanah , osâm misiwê êh-ayâyit kinêpikwah . Soon he could no longer see his wife, for the serpents were all over her.
êkos îsi sipwêhtêw awa nâpêw , wâhyaw êh-nitawih-nipahât mostoswah . Thereupon that man went away; he went far away and killed a buffalo.
êh-kîwêt , nôhtaw tipiskâyiw . It was dark before he got home.
piyis takohtêw ; mistahi nîpâhtêw wîkiwâhk . At last he arrived; in deep darkness he came home from his tramp.

êkosi êh-wâpahk ,
ninêstosin , itwêw awa nâpêw ; Then, the next morning, “I am tired,” said the man;
namoya niwîh-mâcîn , itêw owîkimâkanah . “I am not going to hunt,” he told his wife.
wawêyîw aw iskwêw , ê-wîh-nâtahk wiyâsah . The woman made ready to fetch the meat.
otinam astis , êh-macostêhahk . She took a sinew and scorched it.
ômisi t-êsi-kisiwâkiwiw kâ-wîh-nâtamân wiyâsah ! itwêw aw îskwêw , êh-ati-wayawît . “Even thus let it be near whence I am to fetch the meats!” she said, going out of the tent.

awa nâpêw otinam ôm âstisis kâ-kîh-matostêhamiyit owîkimâkanah , ê-sîpêkipitahk ,
ta-wîh-pîhcâyiw kâ-nâtahk wiyâsah ! êh-itât owîkimâkanah , cikêmâ êh-kisiwâsit . The man took the little bit of sinew which his wife had scorched, and stretched it long, saying, of his wife, “Let it be far whence she fetches the meats!”

seg.q: hâw , hâw , ntawâsimisitik , namoya ês ôyâh kwayask êh-tôtahk kikâwiyiwâw , kâ-kinwêsk kâ-nikohtêt .
seg.gloss: “Come, my children, it seems that your mother who has left has been acting in no becoming way, when always so long she was at gathering firewood.
I have seen what she did; it is hateful to me.

p.seg: tapasîk , itêw , Flee,” he told them;
niwîh-nipahâw kikâwiyiwâw , itêw . “I am going to kill your mother,” he told them.
apasoy ohpipitam . He pulled up a tent-pole.
hâw , nitawâsimisitik , ôtah kwayasitêk ; tapasîk ! itwêw . “Come, my children, go into this hole; flee!” he said.
êkwah ôki nâpêsisak êkotah pîhtokêwak . Then those boys went in there.
kâw êkotah astâw apasoy , êh-tapasiyit otawâsimisah . He put back the tent-pole, and his children fled.

êkwah awa nâpêw otinêw askihkwah êkwah cîkahikan , ê-sipwêhtêt , êh-itohtêt ôhi mistikwah kâ-kîh-pa-pakamahwâyit owîkimâkanah . Then that man took a kettle and an axe and went, off, going to that tree which his wife had struck.

ômis îtwêw , êh-otinahk mistik , êh-pa-pakamahwât ôhi mistikwah :
ninâpêmitik , nitakohtân ! itêw . Taking up a stick of wood and repeatedly striking the tree, he said, “O my husbands, I have come!”

pôtih êh-pê-wayawiyit kinêpikwah , cîkahwêw ; nipahêw , êkotah askihkohk mihkoh êh-ati-sîkinahk ; wiy ôhi wêpinêw . Then, look you, when the serpents came forth, he hacked them with the axe and killed them, but always poured the blood into the kettle; what was left of them he threw away.
piyê-wayawiyici , ati-nipahêw , askihkohk tahk êh-astât mihkoh . He kept killing them as they came forth, and always put the blood in the kettle.
piyis kahkiyaw nipahêw ôhi kinêpikwah . At last he had killed all of those serpents.
êkosi kîwêw ; kîwêhtatâw oma mihkoh . Thereupon he went home; he took the blood home with him.
êkwah êwakô kîsisam . Then he heated it.
êkwah êh-ay-apit , piyisk kêkâc tipiskâw ; êkoyikohk kâ-takohtêyit owîkimâkanah , êh-pêtâyit wiyâs . As he sat there, at last it began to grow dark; only then did his wife arrive, bringing the meat.

omis îtwêw aw îskwêw :
tâpwêh wâhyaw kikîh-nipahâw mostos ! itwêw aw iskwêw ; Thus spoke that woman: “Truly far off did you kill the buffalo!” she said;
kêsiskaw nika-nikohtân ; sâm kiyipah ta-tipiskâw , itwêw . “First I shall get firewood; soon it will be dark,” she said.
cêskwa ! itwêw awa nâpêw ; “Wait!” said the man;
pitah mîcih , itêw owîkimâkanah ; “First eat this,” he told his wife;
om ê-kîh-osîhtâyân mihkoh ta-mîciyan , itêw . “Eat this blood which I have prepared,” he told her.
namoya ; osâm nipapâsêyihtên ê-wîh-nikohtêyân , itwêw aw îskwêw . “No; I must hurry and get my firewood,” said the woman.
kêsiskaw mîcisoh ; kayâs kâ-kîh-mîcisoyan , itêw owîkimâkanah . “First eat; it is a long time since you have eaten,” he said to his wife.
êhag , itwêw aw îskwêw . “Very well,” said the woman.
pîhtokêw , ômah mihkoh êh-otinahk , êh-minihkwêt . She went into the tipi and took the blood and drank it.
î ! tâpwê ê-wîhkasiniyik awa ! itwêw aw îskwêw . “Ooh! Truly this creature's blood tastes good!” she said.
kinisitospitên cî ? itêw awa nâpêw . “Do you recognize the taste of it?” the man asked her.
êhag ; mihkoh mâk ôma , itwêw awa iskwêw . “Yes, why, this is blood,” said she.

kinâpêm-mihkoh ! itêw awa owîkimâkanah . “Your husband's blood!” he said to his wife. LB on {kinâpêm-mihkoh}: “Your husbands blood” would be {kinâpêmak omihkowâw}; what we have here is a nonce-formation on the model of the normal type {kinêpiko-mihkoh}: “snake-blood”, in which the first member is a species of animal.

nâ , mâkw âwa nika-kakwâhyakihikoh ! itwêw aw îskwêw , êh-ati-wayawît , êh-itohtêt ôhi mistikwah . “Heavens, but he has frightened me!” cried the woman, as she left the tent and went to that tree. LB on {mâkw âwa}: For {mâk âwa, mâkah awa}; so often, on the model of {êwakw âwa, êwakoh awah} and similar combinations, where the first word ends in {-o}.

mistik êh-otinahk , êh-pa-pakamahwât ôhi mistikwah ,
ninâpêmitik , nitakosinin ! itwêw aw iskwêw , pêyak êh-apisîsisiyit kâ-pê-wayawiyit . Taking up a stick and beating at the tree, “O my husbands, I have come!” called the woman, and one tiny little one came out.
kisiwâsiw ; êkwah kîwêw . She was angry; she went home.
êkwah awa nâpêw cîkahikan otinam , kisiwâk ê-pê-ayâyit owîkimâkana . Then that man took an axe, as his wife came near.

ômis îtwêw aw iskwêw :
kikisiwâhin kâ-mêscihacik ninâpêmak ! itwêw . Thus spoke the woman: “You have angered me by killing all my husbands!” she cried.
ê-wîh-pîhtokêyit , kâ-cîkahwât owîkimâkanah ; kîskikwêtahwêw owîkimâkanah . As she was about to enter the lodge, he struck his wife with the axe; he chopped off his wife's head.
êkosi êh-tapasît , hâ , ispimihk êh-itohtêt . Then he fled; way up aloft he went.

seg.q: hâw , ayîsiyiniw cêskwah ôtêh nîkân tit-ôhpikiw ;
seg.gloss: “Now, off in the future man will grow into being;

p.seg: niy êwakô , itwêw awa nâpêw . That will be I,” said the man.
êkwah aw iskwêw ostikwân tihtipipayiyiw , êh-ntonawât onâpêma . Then that woman's head went rolling, as she sought her husband.
piyisk kiskêyihtam tântêh êh-itohtêyit onâpêma . At last she perceived whither her husband had gone.

seg.gloss: “There, my husband, you were fond of them; you shall have buttocks!
Go follow our husband, 0 my buttocks!”
seg.note: The father turns into the constellation called {okînânis}. As to the buttocks, the Menomini have a constellation {awêhseh osîkan}: “Bear's Rump”.

p.seg: êkwah awa oma ostikwân oma tihtipipayiw , êh-ntonawât otawâsimisah . Then that head went rolling, as she sought her children.
miskawakwâwê , nika-mêscihâwak kitawâsimisak , itêw owîkimâkanah . “If I find them, I shall kill off your children,” she called to her husband.
misiwê ntonikêw awa tihtipistikwân . That Rolling Head searched everywhere.
piyisk miskam itah kâ-kwayasitêyit otawâsimisah , êkwah êh-pimitisahwât . At last she found the place where her children had gone into the ground, and she started in pursuit of them.
wâhyaw kih-wayawîwak ôk âwâsisak , êh-tapasîcik . Far off those children had emerged and gone on in their flight.
êwako , ôki nâpêsisak , wîsahkêcâhk êwako âskaw êh-nayômât osîmisah . As to those boys, Wisahketchahk from time to time would carry his little brother on his back.
piyisk kisiwâk ayâyiwa okâwiyiwâwa , ôhih tihtipistikwânah . At last quite near was their mother, that Rolling Head.
ntawâsimisitik , pêhik ! nka-nôhâw kisîmis , itêw . “My children, wait for me! I want to suckle your little brother,” she called to them.
piyisk aw âwâsis mâtôw . Soon that child cried.
nistêsê , pêhâtân kikâwiyinaw ! itwêw . “Big Brother, let us wait for our mother!” he said.
namoya ! ê-wîh-nipahikoyahk anah kikâwiyinaw ! itêw . “No! Our mother there wants to kill us!” he told him.

ntowâsimisitik , pêhik ! tahk êh-itât , piyisk kisiwâk êh-êh-ayâyit ,
hâw , itwêw wîsahkêcâhk ,
sîpiy otah ta-wîh-ayâw ! “My children, wait for me!” it kept saying to them, and at last had come very near, when, “Here,” said Wisahketchahk, “Let there be a river here!”
êh-itwêt , âtakâmikisin , kâ-wâpamât cahcakiwah . When he spoke thus, there was a stream blocking his path, and there he saw a crane.
nikâwiyinân ê-wîh-nipahiyâhk , itêw . our mother wants to kill us,” he said to it.

êhag , itikwak ;
hahâw , nôssimitik ! “Very well,” it told them; “Come, my grandchildren!”
âsay kisiwâk pê-ayâyiwa okâwîwâwa . By this time their mother had come very close.
êkosi nayômikwak , ê-wîh-âsawahamiyit . The crane took them on its back and was about to cross the water.
âsay êkotah okâwiywâwah kâ-takohtêyit . Their mother arrived.

seg.note: LB on {câhcak}: For {câhcakiw}: “crane”; she makes a personal name of it by dropping the final {-iw}, cf. e.g., {cîhcîkwâyôw}: “Gnawed-Tail” (as a man's name), for {cîhcîkwâyôwêw}: “he is gnawed at the tail.”

seg.gloss: I am sad with longing to suckle my child.”

p.seg: êkâya tâpwêhtaw , nimosô ! itêw wîsahkêcâhk . “Do not believe her, Grandfather!” Wisahketchahk told it.
pihkohôw wîsahkêcâhk . Wisahketchahk was taken across.
êkwah awa cahcakiw êkotêy isicimêw . Then the crane swam back yonder.
âstam ! itwêw awa tihtipistikwân ; Come here!” cried that Rolling Head;

seg.gloss: I am sad with longing to suckle my child.

p.seg: ahpôh kika-wîkimitin , itêw . If you like, I will even lie with you,” she told it.

âhag , itwêw awa câhcakêw ;
hâw , ka-nayômitin . “Very well, said the crane; “Come, I will take you on my back.”
tâpwê nayômêw . It took her on its back.
êkâya waskawî ; nkâ-kîtimihkawisin , ê-wîsakêyihtah ospiskwan . “Do not move; my spine is very sensitive,” meaning that it had a pain in its back.
êkwah sipwêhtêw . Then it started off.
pakastawêpayiw awa tihtipistikwân . into the water went that Rolling Head.

omis îtwêw awa cahcakiw ;
hâw , cêskwah nîkân ôtêh ayîsiyiniw kit-ôhpikiw ; Thus spoke the crane: “There, off in yon future time man will come into being;

namêw
kik-êsiyihkâtikwak , itêw ôhih tihtipistikwânah . 'Sturgeon,' they will call you,” it said to that Rolling Head. LB: But the same informat tells me that Wisahketchak's mother is now the constellation called {cihcipistikwân}: “Rolling-Skull.”

êkwah tâpwê mistahi mâtôw awa wîsahkêcâhk osîmisah , êh-wâpamât okâwiyah êh-pakastawêhomiht . Then truly Wisahketchahk's little brother wept much, when he saw his mother thrown into the water. LB on {osîmisah}: This construction, joining a non-obviative pronominal particle ({awa}) to an obviative noun, and using non-obviative verbs with the combination is usual in Menomini, but decidedly awkward in Cree.
nisîmis , êkaya mâtoh ; ê-kih-wînipahikoyahk kikâwiyinaw , itêw osîmisah . “Little Brother, do not weep; it is because our mother wanted to kill us,” he told his little brother.
êkotah ay-ayâwak sîpîhk , êh-ma-mêtawêhât osîmisah . There they stayed by the river, and he amused his little brother by making him play.
kîtahtawê kâ-wâpamât ksêyiniwah , ôsihk êh-pêh-pimiskâyit . Then at one time he saw an old man who came paddling a canoe.

ôhih osîmisah pâkahatôwânisah êh-mêtawâkêyit , ômisi itêyihtam awa kisêyiniw :
ohpiwêpinâci ôtah ka-pê-pôsipayiyiwah ! itêyihtam . As Wisahketchahk's little brother played there with his ball, the old man thought: “When he throws it aloft, let it fall here into my canoe!”
êy-ohpiwêpinât aw âwâsis pâkahâcôwânisah , êkotê pahkisiniyiwa . When the child threw his little ball up into the air, there it fell.
otinêw , êh-at-sipwêcimêt . He took it and started to paddle away.
êkwah tâpwê mâtôw awa nâpêsis . Then truly that little boy cried.

nimosôh , itêw aw wîsahkêcâhk ,
pê-kapâwêpin nisîmis opâkahâcowânisah ! “Grandfather,” Wisahketchahk called to him, “Throw my little brother's ball back here to the shore!
êkwanih ohci ôkîskowêmohikoh ! itêw . That is what would make him stop crying!” he told him.

êkosi ê-wîh-nâtât , otapoyiwa êkotah êh-ati-mitimêyâhtawêt wîsahkêcâhk , kâ-pôsiwêpahokot ôhi ksêyiniwa . When, accordingly, Wisahketchahk came to fetch it, and was climbing out by holding on to the paddle, the old man threw him down into the canoe. CHECK otapoyiwa (?otapôyiwa) HCW: contract
êkos ê-ati-sipwêhtêyit , êh-nakatâcik osîmisah . Then he started off, so that they left Wisahketchahk's little brother behind.
êkwah tâpwê mistahi mâtoyiwa . The child wept bitterly.
nimosôh , kikitimahânaw nisîmis ! nâtâtân ! itêw . “Grandfather, we are making my little brother unhappy! Do let us go get him!” he said to the old man.
namoya tâpwêhtam ô kisêyiniw . The old man paid no heed.
piyis wâhyaw ayâw . Soon he was far off.

kîtahtawê awa awâsis kâ-mâtot îtwêw :
nistêsê , tâpwê kikitimahin kâ-nakasiyan ! itwêw ; Presently that child that was weeping cried out: “Big Brother, truly you are making me unhappy by leaving me!
nicawâc nika-mahîhkaniwin , itwêw aw âwâsis , êh-ati-sipwêpahtât . All I can do is turn into a wolf,” cried the child, and ran away from there.
